channel.title: Java Bug System
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [JDK-8318854] [macos14] Running any AWT app prints Secure coding warning
item.description:
When I run Swingset2 with the JDK 22 b19 & b20, I am getting the following warning . This warning is not seen in any JDK 22 builds.
WARNING: Secure coding is not enabled for restorable state! Enable secure coding by implementing NSApplicationDelegate.applicationSupportsSecureRestorableState: and returning YES.

Host details where this is reproduce
OS - Sonoma 14.1
H/W type : Mac Mini 2018
Processor : Intel Core i7
Graphics : Intel UHD Graphics 639
item.summary: [macos14] Running any AWT app prints Secure coding warning

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

[~aivanov] [~rkannathpari] The test cases and testing scenarios (xls sheet) related to this fix is added to the attachment section. Please let me know in case you have any further questions.
Run SwingSet2 using JDK 22 b27 and Secure coding warning is seen any more.

Changeset: 940f67c1
Author: Harshitha Onkar <honkar@openjdk.org>
Date: 2023-11-29 21:53:22 +0000
URL: https://git.openjdk.org/jdk/commit/940f67c1a62c6f9462266f3a108649aca114cffa

Tested sharedDelegate null scenarios using Embedded JFX and SWT. In case of SWT it creates a NSApp of type SWTApplication similar to new JFX changes (where JFX NSApp is of type NSApplicationFX). Embedded SWT test case added to attachment section [Requires swt.jar to run the test].

Updated testing scenarios xls sheet added.

Testing scenarios include combinations of with/without JDK fix, with/without JFX fix, environment var values (when applicable) for Pure AWT/Swing, Pure FX, Swing components in FX window and FX components in Swing container. Testing done on older macOS and macOS 14.

A pull request was submitted for review.
URL: https://git.openjdk.org/jdk/pull/16569
Date: 2023-11-08 19:49:48 +0000
The env variables being used as part of this fix are for debugging only and should NOT be used for application purpose. As such they will NOT be documented.
Code updated - usage of env vars. Testing in progress.

> I can't imagine finishLaunching is called in the first (by which you meanwhen AWT is embedded in FX ) case,
since that's code on NSApplicationAWT which surely is not created in such a case.

This is true. finishLaunching() is not called in first case - AWT is embedded in FX. Confirmed this through logging.

I can't imagine finishLaunching is called in the first (by which you meanwhen AWT is embedded in FX ) case,
since that's code on NSApplicationAWT which surely is not created in such a case.

[~prr] [~kcr]

Regarding the issue in the first scenario, I wanted to check if I was logging at the right setDelegate call in ApplicationDelegate.m

I was logging the "setDelegate called" msg in OSXAPP_SetApplicationDelegate, going over the code again, I see it takes in the new delegate as the parameter. Are we suppose to check in finishLaunching() method of ApplicationDelegate.m ?

void OSXAPP_SetApplicationDelegate(id <NSApplicationDelegate> newdelegate)
{
AWT_ASSERT_APPKIT_THREAD;
    applicationDelegate = newdelegate;
    if (NSApp != nil) {
        NSLog(@"AWT setDelegate called >>>");
        [NSApp setDelegate: applicationDelegate];

        if (applicationDelegate && qad) {
            [qad processQueuedEventsWithTargetDelegate: applicationDelegate];
            qad = nil;
        }
    }
}

" ACTUAL: AWT NSApplication's setDelegate called as seen in the log. This is not the expected behavior and a new JBS will be created to investigate this further."

I see that we create the delegate if the installed NSApplication type is not a sub-classed one.
I don't understand the logic behind that but I expect we inherited it from the Apple contributions back > 10 years ago ..
Surely you can't tell what the existing NSApplication expects from the delegate by whether or not it is a sub-class ?
Sub-classing is actually atypical for NSApplication.

> Well, that's not success. WITHOUT your change, what is the failure ?

Without the fix the Warning msg was present in the std.err as seen in the following log. But this was probably an intermittent issue that I saw. When I tested on another macOS 14 it passed. I can run this test again to verify.

 stdout: [];
 stderr: [2023-10-27 23:52:20.816 java[1054:7016] WARNING: Secure coding is not enabled for restorable state! Enable secure coding by implementing NSApplicationDelegate.applicationSupportsSecureRestorableState: and returning YES.
]
 exitValue = 0
java.lang.RuntimeException: stderr was not empty
at jdk.test.lib.process.OutputAnalyzer.stderrShouldBeEmpty(OutputAnalyzer.java:132)
at NonEmptyErrorStream.main(NonEmptyErrorStream.java:53)
at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.DirectMethodHandleAccessor.invoke(DirectMethodHandleAccessor.java:103)
at java.base/java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:580)
at com.sun.javatest.regtest.agent.MainWrapper$MainTask.run(MainWrapper.java:138)
at java.base/java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:1570)

Following 2 scenarios were tested with JavaFX.

1. Embedding Swing content in an FX window - Test: SimpleSwingNodeTest.java (Not an embedded app)

     EXPECTED: In this case FX will create NSApplication, therefore AWT ApplicationDelegate should NOT be installed.
     ACTUAL: AWT NSApplication's setDelegate called as seen in the log. This is not the expected behavior and a new JBS will be created to investigate this further.


2023-11-01 12:25:40.243 java[92753:12085159] FX NSApplication initWithEnv()
2023-11-01 12:25:40.262 java[92753:12085156] >>>> isEmbedded App ??? 0
2023-11-01 12:25:40.279 java[92753:12085156] >>>> FX setDelegate called - IF BLOCK
2023-11-01 12:25:40.564 java[92753:12085156] AWT ApplicationDelegate init()
2023-11-01 12:25:40.565 java[92753:12085156] >> AWT OSXAPP_SetApplicationDelegate::setDelegate called >>>>

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

2. Embedding FX content in a Swing window - Test: SimpleJFXPanel.java (Embedded app)
    
     EXPECTED: NSApplication created by AWT Toolkit.
     ACTUAL: NSApplication is indeed created by AWT Toolkit as can be seen in the log.


2023-11-01 12:22:20.176 java[92700:12083372] AWT QueuingApplicationDelegate init()
2023-11-01 12:22:20.233 java[92700:12083372] AWT ApplicationDelegate init()
2023-11-01 12:22:20.233 java[92700:12083372] >> AWT OSXAPP_SetApplicationDelegate::setDelegate called >>>>
2023-11-01 12:22:20.461 java[92700:12083437] FX NSApplication initWithEnv()
2023-11-01 12:22:20.461 java[92700:12083372] >>>> isEmbedded App ??? 1
createScene: calling Platform.runLater
Create scene
Setting the scene on the EDT
KCR: Done
You can use the SimpleSwingNodeTest attached to JDK-8298796.
Thanks for the details Phil. I'll check by adding it to QueuingApplicationDelegate and test it out.

I see that in the finishLaunching method of the NSApplicationAWT class we have this code

    if (applicationDelegate) {
        [self setDelegate:applicationDelegate];
    } else {
        qad = [QueuingApplicationDelegate sharedDelegate];
        [self setDelegate:qad];
    }

AppKit will call this some time after we've initialiased the NSApplicationAWT but since we create
the ApplicationDelegate instance later, I think this this is generally (always ?) called before
applicationDelegate is set.

So QueuingApplicationDelegate also needs to implement this applicationSupportsSecureRestorableState protocol and return YES.

I think adding that to what you already tried may be sufficient.


But PS, you should check that we never install applicationDelegate on someone else's NSApplication.

I don't know what it is that triggers the first call of this delegate method, clearly it happens even if you never
create a window.
But I do see that we install our delegate some time AFTER creating our NSApplication.
So there's a period of time in which there is no delegate installed (at least not our delegate).
On top of that I see several other potential complexities
(1) Splashscreen creates NSApplicationAWT - it has to - and this happens long before we get into loading AWT.
So if testing with SwingSet2, which uses SplashScreen, you aren't looking at the same flow as just
Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit(). This needs to work for both cases.
(2) We need to make sure we understand what this means for embedded scenarios. This could mean JavaFX, SWT, and other scenarios where an app creates the NSApplication. Logically it would seem that in such a case it would be on the creator of that to handle it, since I expect we should not be installing our delegate in such a case, because we aren't the application.
(3) Installing too late may be worse than not installing at all as my guess is that whenever AppKit wants to save state it calls this method. I am not sure what it means if an earlier NO changes to YES.

So although I'm not sure exactly where / how, my intuition is we need to install a delegate earlier, just not sure how much earlier, and I'm not sure if it really needs to be the one we want for the long term, or can be a temporary one just to respond to this question. But I do think some methods will need to provide the same answer and we should understand the embedded scenario.

Following are the Apple docs regarding NSApplicationDelegate and the method.
https://developer.apple.com/documentation/appkit/nsapplicationdelegate?language=objc
https://developer.apple.com/documentation/appkit/nsapplicationdelegate/3762521-applicationsupportssecurerestora?language=objc
 
Going by the Apple docs, added applicationSupportsSecureRestorableState() to ApplicationDelegate.m, which contains other app handlers such as quit handler and reopen app handler. With this fix still seeing the warning in the logs on macOS14.
Added applicationSupportsSecureRestorableState() to src/java.desktop/macosx/native/libawt_lwawt/awt/ApplicationDelegate.m but this change doesn't seem to suppress the warning.

"restorable state" is for that "Reopen windows after logging back in ?" question you get asked when logging out / rebooting etc.
But we don't support that. macOS will save whatever state it can, but we certainly don't participate in restoring it.
But I can't find anything on NSApplication or NSApplicationDelegate to just opt out.
So we may have to set this to YES in the absence of alternatives.

Solution is to implement the below method and make it return true in AppDelegate.m as mentioned here -
https://developer.apple.com/documentation/macos-release-notes/appkit-release-notes-for-macos-14#Restorable-State

- (BOOL)applicationSupportsSecureRestorableState:(NSApplication*)app {
  return YES;
}

These are tests that fail on macOS 14 because of this (there may be more but these are the ones I've seen so far)

java/awt/font/JNICheck/FreeTypeScalerJNICheck.java
java/awt/Robot/NonEmptyErrorStream.java
javax/swing/UI/UnninstallUIMemoryLeaks/UnninstallUIMemoryLeaks.java

More or less as I speculated in https://bugs.openjdk.org/browse/JDK-8316016, it seems this is triggered by using a newer toolchain.
I'm sure it is not a coincidence that we bumped the Xcode version used to build JDK 22 b19. https://bugs.openjdk.org/browse/JDK-8317560
Unfortunately this is now causing MORE noise in macOS 14 testing because several tests expect that a message on stderr means the test failed.

This affects all AWT apps on macoS 14
"java.awt.Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit()" is sufficient to trigger it.
And that line of code is implicit in every AWT app.
We need to fix this one soon.
